TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed ParameterTranslationMode extends System.Enum

Docs.summary: Indicates how parameterized collections are translated into SQL.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.ParameterTranslationMode Constant = int32(1)

Docs.summary: Instructs EF to translate the collection to a set of constants: WHERE [x].[Id] IN (1, 2, 3).

remarks.para: This can produce better query plans for certain query types, but can also lead to query plan bloat.

Note that it's possible to cause EF to translate a specific collection in a specific query to constants by wrapping the parameterized collection in : Where(x => EF.Constant(ids).Contains(x.Id). This overrides the default.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.ParameterTranslationMode MultipleParameters = int32(0)

Docs.summary: Instructs EF to translate the collection to a set of parameters: WHERE [x].[Id] IN (@ids1, @ids2, @ids3).

remarks.para: Note that it's possible to cause EF to translate a specific collection in a specific query to parameter by wrapping the parameterized collection in EF.MultipleParameters: Where(x => EF.MultipleParameters(ids).Contains(x.Id). This overrides the default.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.ParameterTranslationMode Parameter = int32(2)

Docs.summary: Instructs EF to translate the collection to a single array-like parameter: WHERE [x].[Id] IN (SELECT [i].[value] FROM OPENJSON(@ids) ...).

remarks.para: This can produce suboptimal query plans for certain query types.

Note that it's possible to cause EF to translate a specific collection in a specific query to parameter by wrapping the parameterized collection in : Where(x => EF.Parameter(ids).Contains(x.Id). This overrides the default.
